so 29 years ago I had this Thermo

Refrigeration it was one of those things
that stuck in my head was a lot like the

didn't know what to do with it and it
was invented in 1858 by this guy
Ferdinand carare but he couldn't
actually build anything with it because
the the the of the tools at the time
it's crazy crazy Canadian named Powell
Crosley commercialized this thing called
the icy ball in 1928 and it was a really
neat idea and I'll get to why it didn't
work but here's how it works there's two
spheres and they're separated in
distance one has a working fluid water
and ammonia the other is a is a
condenser you heat up one side the hot
side the ammonia evaporates and it
recondensed in the other side you let it
cool to room
temperature and then as the ammonia
that because of using ammonia you get
hugely High pressures if you did it if
you heated them wrong they get they
topped 400 PSI the ammonia was toxic it
sprayed everywhere but it's kind of an
interesting thought so the great thing
about 2006 there's a lot of really great

the whole thermodynamics department at
Stanford involved a lot of computational
fluid dynamics we proved that most of
the ammonia Refrigeration tables are
wrong uh we found some non-toxic

vapor pressure
uh brought in a team from the UK there's
a lot of great Refrigeration people that
turned down in the UK and uh built a
test rig and proved that in fact we
could make a low press non-toxic
refrigerator so this is the way it works
you put it on a cooking fire most people
have cooking fires in the world whether
it's Camal dung or wood it heats up for
about 30 minutes cools for an hour you
put it into a container and it'll
refrigerate for 24 hours it looks like
this this is the fifth prototype it's
not quite done weighs about about 8 lb
and this is the way it works you put it
into a 15 L vessel about 3 gallons and
it'll cool it down to just above
freezing 3 degrees above freezing for 24
